body:
@codelipenghui , for docs may need to be updated for pulsar, i summarize the following part. Please help confirm whether it is OK?
concepts and architecture > architecture > broker
reference > pulsar configuration > broker: add a configure item in the configure file
Cookbooks: add a new doc ?

Hi
We are using 2.5.0

What do you mean no incoming traffic ? 
I think the limit of 50k entries and/or the limit of 240 minutes should cause to rollover. Am i right ?

Anyway, what the solution in this case?  The topic has 8 Gb data bas doesn't have any incoming traffic , so the ledger is the open state. So the retention will not occur ever ?

Well, with C++ client, I can use `MessageBuilder::setAllocatedContent` and maintain the payload string myself, eg. use `std::shared_ptr<std::string>`.

With Java client, the internal payload won't be copied, the same byte array could be passed to `ByteBuffer.wrap` in `TypedMessageBuilder.value` method.

The line causing the exception is part of the pulsar code and not Zookeeper. Because Pulsar passes the wrong info to Zookeeper.

Please, re-read my comment as I explain exactly the line causing the error and IT should be easy to modified to correct the error.
That does not answer why this works in the same machine with same disk space with pulsar version 2.4.1...

One more update from me. Apologies if this is a different issue (maybe related?). My issue is happening again, and  the bookie logs are showing:

```bash
10:59:39.505 [LedgerDirsMonitorThread] WARN  org.apache.bookkeeper.bookie.LedgerDirsMonitor - LedgerDirsMonitor check process: All ledger directories are non writable
10:59:39.506 [LedgerDirsMonitorThread] ERROR org.apache.bookkeeper.util.DiskChecker - Space left on device /pulsar/data/bookkeeper/ledgers/current : 2621739008, Used space fraction: 0.95026135 > threshold 0.95.
```
and the clients are saying:

```
WARN  ClientConnection:708 | [192.168.42.55:52176 -> 34.249.195.11:6650] Received send error from server: org.apache.bookkeeper.mledger.ManagedLedgerException: Not enough non-faulty bookies available
WARN  ClientConnection:1234 | [192.168.29.105:43376 -> 192.168.5.249:6650] Could not send pair message on connection: system:9 Bad file descriptor
```
looks like I need to change a retention setting or something like that?

UPDATE: I changed retention settings, scaled bookie down and back up again.. not fixed. Bookie ledger volume is set at 50GB.
And how can we handle it on offloaded parts?

Yes, thanks for the feedback. We are already starting to advance to fix ordering message dispatch related issues when consumer change. And, Will also explain this part in more detail.
And this is a enhancement than a bugfix, would like to remove it from 2.5.2, if it is really needed, we could add it back.

After talking to Ming on slack, I'm pretty confident that I can safely remove the backlog quota.

However, I would say this isn't an ideal solution. Since readers (as opposed to consumers) intend to read _every_ message, and aren't necessarily trying to follow the end of the topic, I think it would make sense to have `consumer_backlog_eviction` and TTLs not apply to reader cursors, and if a reader is reading messages that become deleteable, the reader could have an exception thrown.

Silently skipping messages is a hard to detect and work around.

@jiazhai  It had passed.
@devinbost Can you help review these changes?

> @Omega-Ariston as Penghui mentioned, would you please help add a unit tests for this?

Sorry for the delay, got some business these days...I have added a few lines in `AdminApiTest.java` to cover this issue. Not sure if I got them in the right place tho.
conflict with #6938 will mark this as 2.5.2.

> Step back - what is the real concern preventing you adding a flag?

Giving the false impression that data is retained, when in fact is not. 

Hoping that a reconnection doesn't happen is not a guarantee.

As I already said, the Reader concept was designed in this way. If we want to change or augment the semantics and the guarantees, a flag per-se doesn't accomplish anything.

> In order to make Pulsar as real stream storage, we need to take serious consideration on the reader's behavior.

Again, as I said, there are different ways to guarantee the data retention. Time based is one, a subscription is another. What your describing is essentially a reader that behaves like a subscription.. Then why not just use a subscription if you want to make sure to read the data no matter what?
I apologize for not getting the comments addressed yet. I've had a lot of other responsibilities lately.
@wolfstudy Thanks for picking up this task. These changes all look good to me.
